Welcome to c3py’s documentation!¶

Contents:

class c3py.Chart(name, local_jquery=None, local_requirejs=None, local_d3_js=None, local_c3_js=None, local_c3_css=None)¶

Create and modify a chart.

Parameters:
  • name (str) – The name of the chart. This will be the id of the div that holds the chart. Therefore no two charts in the same document should have the same name.
  • local_jquery (str; default = None) – Path to a local version of jquery. If not provided, one hosted on a CDN is used.
  • local_requirejs (str; default = None) – Path to a local version of requirejs. If not provided, one hosted on a CDN is used.
  • local_d3_js (str; default = None) – Path to a local version of d3js. If not provided, one hosted on a CDN is used.
  • local_c3_js (str; default = None) – Path to a local version of c3js. If not provided, one hosted on a CDN is used.
  • local_c3_css (str; default = None) – Path to a local version of c3’s css. If not provided, one hosted on a CDN is used.
axes = <c3py.axes.Axes object>¶
data = <c3py.data.Data object>¶
get_html_string()¶

Return the HTML string which will draw the chart.

In a Jupyter notebook, this would usually be used as the argument for IPython.display.HTML(), for the interactive chart to be displayed in the notebook.

That is, IPython.display.HTML(chart.get_html_string()).

Returns:str
grid = <c3py.grid.Grid object>¶
